marklogic.body: Most people living up here who care enough to have their voice heard want jobs, but they don't want what GTac was offering, i.e., pollution and the permanent destruction of an ancient mountain range and the wildlife habitat therein.Â They don't want their property values to go down, their quality of life to suffer, or their hunting/fishing Spots to be barracaded and pulverized.Â The proposed mine site already IS a recreational area with gorgeous scenery, valuable timber, abundant wildlife, and trout streams fed by underground water that very likely would have been damaged/dried upÂ by a thousand foot deep, 22-mile-long eyesore.Â The youth you so fondly refer to, at least the ones that cared enough to show up and speak their piece, were against destroying their backyard and/or "growing" their small towns.Â They prefered poverty to the loss of THEIR heritage:Â Quiet wilderness, small town peace of mind, public access land the mine would have made Off limits.Â The horse is dead, please quit beating it.
